question.body: HHb + O2 → HbO Would this process take place in the lungs or in the tissues?

response.feedback: Correct. In the lungs, hemoglobin binds to oxygen and becomes oxyhemoglobin in order to transport oxygen to the body tissues.
Incorrect. In the tissues, the oxyhemoglobin release the oxygen into the tissues and becomes hemoglobin.

part.hint: Consider where oxygen enters the body and where it is used.

response.name: irreversible
response.feedback: Incorrect. If this chemical reaction was irreversible there would be only a single arrow indicating the direction of the reaction.

How would this affect the ability of hemoglobin to do its function?

multiple_choice.choice: It will prevent the HbO2 from delivering oxygen to the tissues
It will prevent the HHb from picking up enough oxygen from the lungs
It will permanently bind to the HHb
It will have no effect on the ability of HHb to perform its function.

response.feedback: Incorrect. If HbO2 can be formed then it can deliver oxygen to the tissues.
